column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country.
*Citizens of Ukraine: Ukrainian arrivals from Poland do not have to provide test results and there is no requirement to quaraantine.
*For Other Travellers: There are no specific COVID-19 entry rule requirements for travellers arriving in Lithuania from EU member states, Schengen Associated countries, Switzerland, Andorra, UK, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican. The EUDCC remains valid in other areas apart from travel.
Travel to Lithuania from non-EU/Schengen countries is restricted to those who are fully vaccinated (14 days after taking the final dose of treatment) and those who qualify for special exemptions. From 15 February, entry is allowed for travellers from select countries.
All travellers must complete the Passenger Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival.
They must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result:
Certificate of recovery is valid for 180 days.
Negative test (within 72 hours).
In addition:
• There is no requirement to self-isolate on arrival.
• Travellers who are not vaccinated or recovered, and who arrive by their own transport from countries other than EU/Schengen Area states, Switzerland, UK, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, and the Vatican, without a negative pre-departure test must take one and pay for it when they arrive.
• All travellers are recommended to take the PCR or antigen test within 3 days of arrival.
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation- travellers from some countries face stricter measures.
Citizens of Ukraine: Ukrainian arrivals from Poland do not have to provide test results and there is no requirement to quaraantine.
For Other Travellers: There are no specific COVID-19 entry rule requirements for travellers arriving in Lithuania from EU member states, Schengen Associated countries, Switzerland, Andorra, UK, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican. The EUDCC remains valid in other areas apart from travel.
column4:
Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNtech, Janssen/Johnson & Johnson, Moderna and AstraZeneca.
Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNtech, Janssen/Johnson & Johnson, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Covishield and Nuvaxovid. For adults over age 18, the primary vaccination certificate is valid for 270 days (it is unlimited for everyone under age 18 and also for adults with a booster shot).
column5:
Latest News: Authorities permit entry for all vaccinated travelers (Schengen Visa Info, 23.02.2022).

International Restrictions:
*From within the EU: [ as below]

*Transit:

Travellers in transit must complete the Passenger Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival.

Transit is allowed for citizens of non-EU/Schengen area countries:

  • On their return to their country of residence;
  • In whose respect a reasoned request has been made by a foreign country;
  • Via the territory of the Russian Federation to Kaliningrad region of the Russian Federation and backward (via Kena railway border checkpoint and Kybartai railway border checkpoint).

Citizens of Ukraine: Ukrainian travellers arriving from Poland do not have to provide test results and there is no requirement for them to quarantine.



*From Third Countries:

Travel to Lithuania from non-EU/Schengen countries is restricted to those who are fully vaccinated (14 days after taking the final dose of treatment) and those who qualify for special exemptions. From 15 February, entry is allowed for travellers from select countries.

All travellers must complete the Passenger Questionnaire 48 hours before arrival.

They must provide proof of vaccination, recovery or a negative test result:

  • Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNtech, Janssen/Johnson & Johnson, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Covishield and Nuvaxovid. For adults over age 18, the primary vaccination certificate is valid for 270 days (it is unlimited for everyone under age 18 and also for adults with a booster shot).
  • Certificate of recovery is valid for 180 days.
  • Negative test (within 72 hours).

In addition:

  • There is no requirement to self-isolate on arrival.
  • Travellers who are not vaccinated or recovered, and who arrive by their own transport from countries other than EU/Schengen Area states, Switzerland, UK, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, and the Vatican, without a negative pre-departure test must take one and pay for it when they arrive.
  • All travellers are recommended to take the PCR or antigen test within 3 days of arrival.

Citizens of Ukraine: Ukrainian travellers arriving from Poland do not have to provide test results and there is no requirement for them to quarantine.

Learn More:

Travel Portal


______________________

You can find the latest information on air travel regulations for this country on the IATA website.

You can also find information about your passenger rights on our portal for citizens.

Documents you need to travel in Europe
Health cover for temporary stays



Internal Restrictions:
*Facemasks: You must wear a medical facemask in all indoor public spaces in Lithuania, including shops, restaurants, businesses, workplaces, museums, theatres, public transport, taxis and educational environments.
Masks should be three layers of non-woven material and bear the CE marking on their marking on their packaging.
For indoor events, such as concerts or sporting events, all spectators must wear FFP2 masks, tightly fitting to the face and covering the mouth and nose.
These rules do not apply to children under the age of six, or people with a medical exemption. If you cannot wear facemasks on medical grounds, you are advised to wear face shields if possible. Exemptions also apply to those doing physical exercise, providing a service that cannot be done with a facemask, or consuming food or drink.
*Public places and services: From 5 January 2022, the Lithuanian Government no long requires individuals to prove their vaccination status in order to access non-essential services. More information on COVID-19 related restrictions to public places and services in Lithuania is available on the KoronaStop website. *If you test positive for COVID-19, you may need to stay where you are until you test negative. You may also need to seek treatment there.
